answer: In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, @PERSON3's life, the overall mood, which encapsulated all the emotions, was one of deep gratitude. It vividly showed how his parents gave him unwavering love throughout his entire life. Both his parents were born and raised in Cuba, and in 1956, they made the brave decision to move to the United States. Starting their lives over again from scratch, they took on any job they could find to make ends meet. Then in 1961, @PERSON2, @CAPS1, was born into this loving environment. Both parents raised him with an abundance of love and meticulous care, gently introducing his Cuban background into his daily life. As @PERSON2 was sharing his story, all readers could clearly sense how incredibly grateful he was to have a family like his. Also, as he recounted his non - blood related family and the memories of how his parents' life changed by moving to @LOCATION2, he genuinely showed the profound respect he held towards them.

Throughout the excerpt from Home the Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez, the author, skillfully manages to maintain a single overall mood. In numerous parts of the story, he fondly tells about how much he adored his childhood, which initially led me to think the mood was nostalgia. However, nowhere does it strongly emphasize that he yearns to return to past times. He consistently declared how loving and selfless his family was, how they readily aided others in need, and how he became like "family" with his neighbors. Due to these aspects, I have found the tone to be one of deep love and admiration towards his parents. This is because he states how his parents were so incredibly brave to leave their well - established lives in Cuba behind just so he could have a far better life. Narciso Rodriguez also remarks numerous times on how his parents selflessly helped so many people in difficult situations. If I were in Rodriguez's position, I would surely love and admire my parents just as much, if not more, for their selfless deeds and the wonderful upbringing they gave to their son.

The mood the author created in the memoir is one of pure love. The author discovers that family doesn't necessarily have to be blood - related. In the author's neighborhood, "despite customs elsewhere, all of these diverse cultures came together in perfect solidarity and warm friendship" (@NUM1). The author deeply loves their parents because they came "as many immigrants do, with the sole purpose of giving their children a better life" (@NUM2). The author is extremely grateful that her parents "Mother and father had come to this country with such remarkable courage, without any prior knowledge of the language or the local culture" (@NUM3). The author's parents gave him a wonderful life by moving to @LOCATION1 and "turned this simple house into a @NUM4", a place filled with love and belonging.

The mood created by the author is to vividly show how Cubans lived and about their unique culture. It also highlights that some people from other cultures could be different. Some don't truly @CAPS1 care about their own cultures, while others, like Narciso's parents, deeply cherish and hold onto their cultural heritage. That is precisely what the author is trying to convey. And it emphasizes that some people should respect their own cultures and not @CAPS2 try to be a different culture just for the sake of it.

The mood created in the memoir is a beautiful blend of happiness and profound gratitude. Narciso is extremely grateful to his parents for moving to @LOCATION1. Even in a new place, they still managed to give him that warm and happy feeling reminiscent of a house in Cuba. His parents carefully passed down their rich culture to him, and he is overjoyed that they did so. Narciso is glad to have lived in the home that they provided, and he appreciates all the wonderful opportunities that he had as a child. He is grateful that his family always came together and had a grand feast filled with Cuban music, engaging activities, and delicious food. His parents selflessly gave up their jobs and had to start their lives over completely from the beginning. Narciso is also grateful that he learned the real and true definition of "family". He is also very thankful to his parents for their boundless love and great sacrifice, which have shaped his life in so many positive ways.

The mood definitely helps you feel and comprehend the story better. The mood is a unique mixture of both happy and sad, primarily because of the poignant way the author states his ideas. For example, the sentence "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" makes me feel a deep sense of sadness because he has grown up, and now everything exists only as memories. However, he also holds onto those happy memories tightly. Most of the other ideas like "I will be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" also carry the same underlying reasons for evoking both happiness and sadness. On the other hand, statements like "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" make me feel genuinely happy that his parents were so determined. Overall, the main idea is about remembering the good and bad times of his life, and the mood for this idea is a complex blend of happy and sad, which enriches the story's emotional depth.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", he/she skillfully incorporated love and passion into the mood. You can clearly tell this by how fondly and strongly Narciso talks about some things. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm houses." In this one sentence alone, you could vividly feel Narciso's intense passion and profound love for this home of theirs. Narciso puts a great deal of heartfelt love and sincere thankfulness into paragraph @NUM1 and @NUM2 when talking about his/her parents. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'... I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." These two sentences are most likely the strongest in Narciso's memoir, and they are also the ones filled with the most passion and meaning. As you can see, in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood Narciso infuses into it is a rich and palpable love and passion, which leaves a lasting impression on the readers.

In the excerpt, the mood created by the author is love. It is a love for family and a love for each other. The author talks about his parents in a loving and respectful way, saying, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author describes all the hardships and efforts his parents went through to make their own and his life better. In doing so, they transformed an ordinary apartment into a place full of love and caring that he will never forget. More importantly, they passed this precious love onto him. The author also talks about his "family" and the love shared between them. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." The author's "family" wasn't completely blood - related. Many people were friends, but very close friends that had become like family and were always warmly welcomed. Finally, the author talks about his community, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." No matter what nationality they were, the community was very close - knit and understanding. It was these basic principles of friendship, trust, love, and caring that were passed onto the author of this excerpt by a variety of people, and they give the excerpt a warm and endearing mood of love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful and fortunate. Narciso Rodriguez talks about being extremely fortunate to have his parents and his heritage of being Cuban. From paragraph @NUM1, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS1 is clearly saying that @CAPS1 was so happy and incredibly lucky to have his parents as parents, which is the main mood that permeates the memoir. Another mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is happiness. @CAPS1 makes the story brim with happiness by saying how wonderful it was to grow up with his family. @CAPS1 also mentions that his family extended to a lot of people in his neighborhood as well. @CAPS1 is truly happy to have such a great family. From paragraph @NUM2, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." These two moods, gratitude and happiness, are the key elements that Rodriguez creates in his memoir, making it a heart - warming read.

The author generally stayed in one mood throughout the story. The mood portrayed in the story was that family and friends are very important, and they play a crucial role in shaping what you will be in the future. This is why the author stressed how deeply thankful he was that his family had come to @LOCATION1 to create a better life for him. Additionally, he was grateful that his friends came over to share their diverse cultures. Also, the author was emphasizing that even in @LOCATION1, it was important to remember his Cuban blood and culture. This is why he says "...and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the enticing aromas of the kitchen." Also, the author says that a home is where great memories are made and where you grow up, and you should never forget the special bond and experiences associated with it. In essence, the author's message is a powerful reminder of the significance of family, friends, and cultural heritage.

The mood that the author creates in this story is a deeply @CAPS1 sad mood. But it is also @CAPS2, @CAPS3 as the guy in it is getting a new Home and a new Life @CAPS3. His parents @CAPS5 are making efforts to provide him with a better future @CAPS6. This blend of sadness and hope makes the story quite poignant.

The mood in the memoir that the author creates is a very warm and relaxed sort of mood. The way the author tenderly tells you about his parents; their selflessness and the way they consistently put their kids first before themselves really just makes you introspect about your own parents and how good they are to you and what self - sacrificing things they would do for you. The way the author vividly talks about his home makes you envision all the colors in the house. I think that the house would be a golden â€“ red color, with touches of yellow, white, brown and orange on the insides. It reminds me of the way they would have cooked. They would have cooked with colorful peppers, fresh onions, soft tortillas and fragrant oils. It makes you think about what colors adorn your home and what delicious dishes you would cook with. The music sounds wonderful. Even though they don't precisely demonstrate what it actually sounds like, you can easily imagine it. I imagine it softly laying in the background while all the adults are busily cooking and the kids are merrily playing in colorful rooms with the golden sunlight gently shining in through an open window. I truly love the mood that this memoir puts me in as it brings a sense of peace and nostalgia.

The mood of the memoir is a very upbeat, happy mood of how @PERSON1 grew up in Newark, New Jersey in a very Cuban family and vividly tells the story of how Narciso went through his childhood. This memoir really emphasizes the strong connection and deep love that Narciso had with his parents and his home. It kind of makes you think that there is more to a house than just walls and a ceiling and that maybe it's an integral part of a family, a place where memories are made and love is shared.

Describe the mood created by the author in the memoir. The mood created by the author in the memoir is that she had a hard time growing up because her parents kept on moving. By the age of twenty - seven years old, Narciso Rodriguez was living with her family in a one - apartment room. When she was growing up, there was racism in the area where she was growing up. Despite these hardships, when she was growing up, her mother and father patiently taught her how to cook, and the number one thing she learned is how to love someone unconditionally. This shows that even in difficult times, there was a glimmer of hope and love in her life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy, enjoyable, and worth living. I say happy because they had a loving family to be with, and other kind - hearted friends to help them if anything went wrong. I say enjoyable because the author talks about how they (main character) had the first birthday filled with joy and the first friend who brought new experiences. I would enjoy all my birthdays if I was that person and also cherish my first friend. I also said worth living because they had food on their table every day, ensuring basic sustenance. And nothing in the memoir said anything about struggling. This is why I firmly explain the mood as happy, enjoyable, and worth living, a mood that makes the story a delightful read.

The mood created by the author in this memoir was very loving and caring for their friends, family, and everyone around them. For instance, it specifically mentions how his mom would always keep the door open for whoever was going through a rough time, patiently waiting until they were back on their feet. This was because she knew that they would do the same for her and her family. Also, the mood is very thankful. Narciso truly admires everything that he's accomplished in life and all the people he's helped out. He's genuinely thankful for all the friends he has and the care they show for him and his family. He seizes every opportunity he gets in life to express his gratitude. The mood also shows how something small can turn out to be significant on the inside. Despite living in a small place, Narciso has managed to achieve so much. Overall, the author effectively conveys these heart - warming and appreciative emotions throughout the memoir.

In this memoir, the author creates a mood that is filled with love. The author deeply loves his parents for all the sacrifices they made to come to @LOCATION1. They left behind their families, friends, and careers in their home country, all with the selfless goal of giving their children a better life. The author really appreciates everything they've done for him and is truly grateful. The author vividly describes the "warmth" of his kitchen. It is filled with love and rich culture, with the great aroma of their parents' delicious cooking wafting through the air and the music from his culture playing softly in the background. He loves this homely atmosphere. The author also details how his family is @CAPS1 extremely close, and so are their friends. There is a strong love that they share for each other. The memoir says "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." @CAPS1 They regarded people who weren't really family as family. They supported and helped each other out, whether it was family or friends. This is what creates the mood to be one of love. In this memoir, the author effectively creates a mood that is unmistakably LOVE.

The author of this memoir created a mood about family. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This poignant quote tells that the mood created by the author makes the reader realize just how hard their parents work to give their children a better life and a quality education. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'." This statement also makes the reader feel like there is a lot more to a family than what it might initially seem. A family gives one life and imparts the lesson of love. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote tells that home is not just a place where one resides, but it is about the relationships that are formed and nurtured there. These were some of the beautiful moods created by the author in the memoir, which effectively convey the true essence of family.

The mood created by this author is clearly grateful. The author shows how Narciso could never stop expressing his gratitude. He genuinely loved the feeling his mom and dad made him have, and all the things they did for him. By moving into a place to call home for Narciso, his parents had a profound impact on his mood, making him endlessly grateful. When we say Narciso's mood is grateful, we mean he is constantly and deeply thankful for all that he has thanks to his parents. In this short autobiography, Narciso makes the reader feel and understand that he is happy with the life he has. As this short story creates the mood of being grateful, you can clearly sense how he feels as you read the repeated phrase throughout the article, "I will always be grateful to my parents...". This consistent expression of gratitude effectively conveys the overall mood of the memoir.

The mood set by the author in the memoir is a "home is home" kind of mood, evoking a feeling of a great family, wonderful friendships/relationships, and open - armed hospitality. He specifically mentions the fact that his parents always lent a helping hand to friends and family in need and were incredibly selfless towards other people. He elaborates on how he and his family used to gather together and have meals as a united family. He says he is truly grateful for the spirit and generosity instilled in him by his parents at a young age. He gives the reader a strong sense of comfort and generosity. He sincerely thanks his family for expressing spirit, generosity, and selflessness towards people. Through these descriptions, the author successfully creates a warm and inviting mood that makes the reader appreciate the value of family and kindness.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is deeply grateful, genuinely joyful, and whole - heartedly loving. The mood is grateful because the author's parents were truly such wonderful and exemplary people, whose values and actions made the author look up to them with admiration. The author even sincerely says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their unwavering love and selfless sacrifice." The mood is also joyful because, although the author lived in just a simple, unassuming house, inside, there was always the lively sound of music filling the air, and he was strongly influenced by his rich Cuban culture. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the enticing aromas of the kitchen." After all, a house is only a "home" if you feel truly welcome and loved, and that is exactly how the author felt every day. Lastly, the mood is loving because in his home, his parents whole - heartedly welcomed anyone who needed help. An example from the memoir is, "My parents kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Overall, the author kept the mood lively and definitely happy, although this happiness persevered through difficult times like segregation, showing the power of family and love.

In the memoir, the author created a very upbeat and infectious mood. He clearly is extremely grateful for his family, and had a truly happy childhood filled with precious memories. He carefully pointed out the parts of his home and situation that could have been negative for him while growing up, such as the cultural adjustments and financial hardships. But then he effectively cancelled those negative things out by noting the positive aspects of each situation. For example, in the memoir he wrote about how his family had immigrated to the United States, and how they had good, stable jobs in Cuba, but then had to start all over with low - paying jobs once they got here. He said that this was really hard for them, but he found a positive way to look at the situation. He did this by writing about how his parent's situation taught them and him to always work hard with determination, and never give up hope. So overall, he made what could have been a depressing story, have an upbeat and happy mode. He even made the story teach you a valuable lesson about hard work and the importance of family and giving to others, leaving a lasting impression on the readers.

The mood created by the author of the memoir is warm, cozy and deeply family - oriented. From the very beginning, the author vividly describes the home as more of a way of life than just a physical space. The author's "parents lovingly created our traditional Cuban home, a significant part of which was the inviting kitchen" (@NUM1). Here, the home is described even more as an integral part of the family, rather than just a building. To enhance the strong feeling of family, the author includes heart - warming stories of hospitality: "My parents always kept their arms and their door wide open to the many people he considered family" (@NUM2). Hospitality is one of the best qualities you need to make a house a true home and the author really emphasizes and stretches that aspect. The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family - oriented, making the readers feel the sense of belonging and love.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a very happy and heart - warming mood in his memoir. One reason the mood is happy is because of the idyllic setting. Narciso describes his house in detail and says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the warm congregation of family and friends, and endless, joyous celebrations that encompassed both, formed the beautiful back - drop to life in our warm home." The author describes a home filled with many good friends and countless good memories that will last a lifetime. Another reason is how sincerely grateful the author sounds. It says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and successful careers in the country they loved." While they had to leave everything behind they did it for their kids and for a new life. The author is genuinely happy that they made such a brave decision. Also, the author credits the house with giving him a real sense of family. Narciso says, "It was here that I learned the real definition of the word 'family.' And for this, I will be forever grateful." Narciso learned a lot in this house and is very happy for that. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, he creates a very happy mood that makes the readers feel the love and warmth of his family.

Based on this memoir, the mood created by the author is a truly great and almost unexplainable mood. In this article, it talks about a young man named @PERSON1 and how his life was from then and now. For example, on paragraph @NUM1, it says he will always be deeply grateful to his parents for their unconditional love and great sacrifices. And how he had always told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that he could have ever done. Also, it describes how Cuban music was so passionate and how he adored it so much, and how his parents turned a simple, ordinary house into a warm and loving home full of memories. Therefore, this is the mood created by the author, a mood that makes the readers feel the power of family and the beauty of cultural heritage.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was one of pure happiness and deep - seated thankfulness. His parents, with their rich Cuban background, imparted a wealth of knowledge to him. They taught him the art of Cuban cooking, from the perfect blend of spices in a traditional stew to the delicate process of making empanadas. In terms of music, they introduced him to the rhythmic beats of salsa and the soulful melodies of bolero. His parents made numerous sacrifices to ensure Narciso felt comfortable and at home. They gave up their own comforts, like having more personal space, to create a warm environment for him. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," Narciso often said. His parents didn't just create a home for their family; they opened their house to others. "My parents always kept their arms and door open to the many people we considered family." They would take in anyone, whether it was a friend in financial trouble or a relative going through a tough time, and let them stay until they got back on their feet. Narciso's parents were pillars of the community, showing love and support and helping out as much as they could, truly making that place feel like home for everyone.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the author skillfully creates a multi - faceted mood that is a blend of seriousness, happiness, and thankfulness. The author approaches the narrative with a serious tone as his family had to confront both economic hardships, such as struggling to pay bills on time, and personal problems, like dealing with the stress of adapting to a new country. However, there was a silver lining. The author was happy living in a neighborhood that was friendly and unified. The neighborhood was filled with immigrants from different countries, each bringing their unique cultures and traditions, creating a rich and diverse community. The author showed deep thankfulness because his parents worked incredibly hard, often taking on multiple jobs, to give him a new life full of opportunities. The memoir not only conveys a positive mood but also provides an accurate portrait of the author's childhood, capturing both the challenges and the joys.

@PERSON1's mood was a delightful mix of happiness and gratitude. @PERSON1 was grateful because he had the precious gift of having his family all together under one roof. His mom and dad were open - hearted about sharing their Cuban culture. They would host cultural events at home, where they'd cook traditional Cuban dishes and play lively Cuban music, allowing @PERSON1 and others to immerse themselves in the culture. He was happy because his life in the new place was far better than it would have been if they had stayed in Cuba. In Cuba, they might have faced limited opportunities, but here, there were new chances for education and a better future. That was @PERSON1's mood, a combination of contentment and appreciation for his new life and his family.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, the mood and feeling of her home and community paint a picture of a truly happy and heartwarming situation. Most people living in a tiny apartment in the city would likely complain that it was too small and cramped, constantly yearning for a mansion on the ocean. However, Narciso found complete happiness in that environment. As she described it, the apartment was always filled with enticing smells, like the aroma of freshly baked Cuban pastries and simmering stews. There was also wonderful music playing, whether it was the sound of a guitar strumming a Spanish ballad or the lively beats of a Cuban band. And there were always great people around, chatting, laughing, and sharing stories. Narciso said the people who contributed the most to her wonderful experience in New Jersey were her parents. They supported and cared for her whole - heartedly while struggling to make ends meet. Despite the financial difficulties, they never showed a hint of sadness. They loved and cared for her unconditionally. Even though Narciso lived in a small apartment in the city, she and her family demonstrated that with love and a positive attitude, you can make the best out of any situation, creating a home full of warmth and memories.

In the memoir @PERSON1, it delves deeply into the concept of making a house a home and a community feel like family. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'Family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" (par @NUM1). Paragraph @NUM1 further elaborates on how growing up in a community that embraced Italian, Spanish, and Cuban cultures was truly special. Despite the cultural differences, everyone came together, putting aside their disparities. The Italians shared their love for pasta and opera, the Spanish brought their flamenco and tapas, and the Cubans contributed their salsa and empanadas. This cultural melting - pot made the community into a close - knit family. Rodriguez speaks very warmly about his childhood, recalling only the good times. The mood of the memoir is one of Rodriguez fondly remembering his culture - filled childhood. "I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love" (par seven). The memoir serves as a dedication to his life and a reflection of all the experiences he had within his family. He writes his memoirs in a loving spirit, passing on his knowledge of what a "family" truly means to his own life and future generations.

In the memoir "@PERSON1 Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives by @PERSON1, the mood is a very important part of the story. The mood in this memoir is definitely thankfulness. The first reason for why the mood of this story is thankfulness is because @PERSON1 is deeply thankful for his Cuban heritage. Through his words, @PERSON1 shows his love for his heritage by stating "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills". @PERSON1 is truly grateful that he has acquired these skills from his great culture, skills that are a part of his identity. The second reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his home. "...Formed the backdrop to life in our warm home", @PERSON1 writes in his memoir. This quote clearly shows that @PERSON1 is thankful for having a nice and cozy place to call his home, a place filled with warmth and memories. The final reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his hard - working parents. "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly", he comments. This undoubtedly shows the author's great respect for his parents and all they have done to ensure he can be happy and healthy. Thankfulness is a mood that suits this memoir very well, and the pride and gratefulness that the author shows for his heritage, home, and parents is truly wonderful, making the memoir a heart - warming read.

The mood created by the author in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very calm and happy. The author manages to create an atmosphere that is very calm and cool. There are no loud or emphasized parts in the text, which gives it a gentle and soothing feel. It is also very happy as it vividly describes a family growing and gradually learning to love each other. Additionally, it depicts friends and more family members having happy times and celebrating together. The happiest line was the last one, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple little house into a home." This line not only shows the happiness but also has a very loving tone to it. Anything about a family coming together is inherently loving, and this memoir successfully captures that loving and happy essence.

The author could have put a lot of different types of mood in the memoir. I think that the mood of the memoir is happy, grateful, and appreciated. I said happy because he vividly talks about everything he does and clearly shows how he enjoys it. Whether it's daily activities or special moments, his joy shines through his words. I said grateful because he is always sincerely thanking his parents and he deeply admires them. He admires them because they came from difficult circumstances to build a good life. They have come a long way to reach a good life and they do everything in their power to maintain it. And he appreciates them for the same reasons I mentioned before. He admires them and always expresses his gratitude for what they have done for him. This is the mood the author has toward writing the story, and it makes the memoir a positive and heart - touching piece.

In Narciso's memoir, I feel joy. I feel joy because Narciso's parents were able to survive against all odds. They came to @LOCATION1, "without any knowledge of the language or culture." As we know, @CAPS1 immigrant families usually do not get on their feet right away, but they did. Within a year, they went from a @NUM1 - room apartment to a @NUM2 - room apartment, which is a remarkable achievement. Joy came to my mind also because they had welcoming arms for their family. In today's world, people are losing their jobs and homes and often have nobody to turn to. However, the Rodriguez family had a place to go. "Countless extended family members came & went - and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms & their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This sense of family and support brings a lot of joy and makes the memoir a truly uplifting read.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is quite evident. The author was grateful to have the chance to grow up in the @LOCATION1. The memoir is titled Narciso Rodriguez. He talks about his life, that he came from Cuba, and that his parents welcome people who come from Cuba. They come "together in a great solidarity and friendship." I think his mood is extremely happy. To see that his parents made something out of nothing is truly inspiring. The author's parents show him through their life, and their teachings have been the basis of his life. I feel the same way because my parents brought me here for a better life. I believe you learn everything from your parents, like how to act and so on. So, yes, I really liked the last sentence he said. He said "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This sentence perfectly sums up the warm and grateful mood of the entire memoir.

Author Narciso Rodriguez vividly describes his deep - seated love and overwhelming happiness towards his family in this heartfelt memoir. He poignantly states how his parents selflessly gave up everything, not for their own gain, but for him and his relatives. The community they moved to was filled with such warmth and joy that it felt like an extended part of his family. Narciso elaborates on how he and his family steadfastly keep their @CAPS1 culture alive, and he truly appreciates this cultural connection. The last sentence, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home", truly encapsulates the essence of his emotions. All of these elements show that throughout this memoir, his mood is a beautiful blend of happiness, love, and gratitude.

The author's mood in the memoir @PERSON1 is clearly thankful. I can discern this because, in paragraph @NUM1, @CAPS1 elaborately talks about his culinary skills and expresses how deeply grateful he is to have these skills passed down to him. This clearly shows that he is extremely thankful for this skill, considering that some people lack the ability to cook, and being able to cook is indeed a precious blessing. It also reveals that he takes great pride in his culture and his identity as a person. @PERSON2 poignantly quotes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In @CAPS2, this quote makes it evident that @PERSON2 is highly appreciative of all that his parents have done for him. It also shows that he loves his parents dearly and seizes every opportunity to express his thanks. Therefore, in the memoir, Narciso radiates a mood of thankfulness.

The author's interpretation of their childhood home effectively sets a mood of love and compassion. He writes about his parents in a manner that clearly informs the reader that they were exceptionally good people. He describes them, along with others in their community, as honest, hard - working, and selfless individuals. He pens the story with a profound sense of appreciation for his parents, family, and life, which is truly admirable. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", the author crafted a consistently happy tone throughout the entire story. In his memoir Home: Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez creates a warm, familial mood that envelops the reader. In the memoir, the author creates a very peaceful mood. He achieves this by using a blunt voice and unusual punctuation. The author's voice is very blunt. Narciso Rodriguez poignantly presents the following definition of family in this memoir. In our neighborhood, despite different customs elsewhere, all of these diverse cultures came together in remarkable solidarity and sincere friendship. My mother and father had come to this country with such incredible courage, without any knowledge of the English language or the American culture. In the United States, they had to start their lives over completely, taking whatever menial work they could find just to make ends meet. I will always be deeply grateful to my parents for their unconditional love and selfless sacrifice. They showed me with their own arduous lives and these precious teachings have been the solid basis of my life. It was in the comforting warmth of the kitchen in this humble little house where a delicious Cuban feast always filled the air with not just the enticing scent and lively music but also vibrant life and pure love. It was here where I learned the real, profound definition of "family". And for this, I will never forget that charming house or its gracious neighborhood or the many valuable things I learned there about how to love whole - heartedly. I will never forget how my parents lovingly turned this simple house into a real home, a place full of memories and affection.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the renowned fashion designer, emphasizes that family is everything. This entire memoir focuses on family. Narciso first describes how he and his family came to live in a cramped one - room apartment. He then said how he and his sister Rawedia Maria are going to move into a more spacious three - room apartment in the future. In the memoir, Narciso said how his parents came from Cuba as immigrants to the United States. Narciso couldn't believe how brave his parents were. His "real grandparents" couldn't leave Cuba until 1970, but his parents managed to sneak out. Narciso said how his house was not a simple house because, in fact, many people lived in it. Some relatives lived upstairs, some downstairs. But the one thing that Narciso keeps saying to his parents is thank you. If they got caught sneaking out of Cuba, they wouldn't be able to live in this nice place that Narciso calls home.

The mood given by the @CAPS1 (In my perspective) is happy because even if you had to move to @LOCATION1, far away from his loved ones, he still managed to find happiness with his family in @LOCATION1. This shows that family bonds can overcome the distance and bring about a positive mood.

In the article "Narciso Rodriguez" by The Blueprints of our lives, the mood of the author in the memoir was that he was deeply thankful for everything he got. So, like, the mood was quiet and loving. Also, I picked loved as a mood because in the article, it says "always filled the air with not just scent in music but life and love. The mood created by the author in the memoir is gentle and a sense of proudness. The author explains of how he felt about his parents who risked everything in order to give him a better future according to paragraph @NUM1. Throughout the whole memoir, the author feels proud of being from Cuba. He shows his pride of being Cuban by elaborately explaining the things he does and the things that they share in his culture. Last but least, he feels thankfulness according to paragraph @NUM2 because, through his parents and things from his country, he learned what family really means. He says "... I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". Through the whole memoir, the author shows proudness of where he came from, from his parents, his country, and his neighborhood, which all contribute to the overall gentle and proud mood.

The mood the author is creating is sad. Because he is vividly talking about his whole family, his house, and how he had so many wonderful and cherished good memories there, along with his first friend. Recalling these things makes the mood heavy with a tinge of melancholy, and this kind of mood is indeed sad as it brings a sense of longing and loss.

In the story "Narciso Rodriguez", I think the author was incredibly grateful and overjoyed at that moment. I believe he was happy because he was laughing about how Narciso was consistently in a good mood. She always had a beaming smile and a positive attitude. Also, he loved how she adored cooking in the kitchen with everyone, sharing recipes and having a great time. Moreover, she still cherished her ritual song that she sang with her family, creating a warm and loving atmosphere. This shows that the story was filled with positive emotions and a sense of togetherness.

The mood that was created by this author was love. It was evident in the way he vividly described his house. "The passionate Cuban music filled the air, gently mixing with the enticing aromas of the kitchen. Cooking and music are usually things you associate with love, and love brings happiness. The author also talks about his "close - knit community of honest, hard - working immigrants who extended a helping hand to people who, not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This also shows that the mood in this memoir is love, the love of cooking, the love of music, and the love of family. Another place where it showed love in the memoir was in this quote. "My Parents always kept their arms and their door wide open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows love because even though these people aren't blood - related, they still look out for each other and knew they had someone reliable to lean on. The apparent mood in this story was love, and the family had an abundance of it, making the memoir a heart - warming read.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is Love. In paragraph @NUM1, it says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the joyful congregation of family and friends, and the endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the idyllic backdrop to life in our warm home." This means that there will always be a deep well of love and a sense of pure happiness in your home if you just respect your friends and your loved ones. When you show respect, you build strong bonds, and these bonds create a loving environment. Life would be good as you are surrounded by people who care about you and share in your joys.

In the memoir, the author creates a mood of love and community. In paragraph two, the author describes his childhood home with words like traditional, passionate, and congregation. These carefully chosen words set the warm and inviting tone for the rest of the memoir in which love and helping the community are key themes. It gives me the distinct feeling that I could walk into their home and be welcomed with open, friendly arms even as a complete stranger. The home seems to radiate a sense of acceptance and kindness. These themes are reinforced in the last few sentences when the author ends by speaking about his gracious neighborhood and how he learned to love. This shows that the love and community spirit were not just limited to the home but extended to the whole neighborhood.

The mood created by the author is happiness and gratefulness. Reading this made me feel very thankful. The author thanks his parents several times. He talks about how he learned how to cook from his parents with patience and care and says "and for which I am eternally grateful" in paragraph @NUM1, and in paragraph @NUM2 "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." I think those specific quotes from the memoirs clearly show how deeply grateful the author is feeling. Reading this made me feel grateful for what I have, and it made me think of all the things my parents did for me and the sacrifices they made. I also think the mood is happy because the author is looking back at his life and states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a warm and loving home." This made my mood become happy as it reminds us of the power of family love. Overall, the memoir effectively conveys the author's emotions of happiness and gratitude.

The mood is a warm, genuinely happy feeling. In this setting, the home is a haven of safety and one of those idyllic, perfect homes where nothing goes awry. It is a caring abode filled with numerous friends and family who have been part of the household for a long time, creating a sense of enduring comfort and joy.

The mood that the author creates is a kind of contented happiness for what he has. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of their cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This quote clearly shows how the author views the different cultures uniting together, highlighting the positive and inclusive atmosphere in the neighborhood.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author's narrative is truly shocking. First, on page 23 paragraph 4, Rodriguez wrote, "I would not know my 'real' grandparents... leave Cuba." Here, Rodriguez is talking about how she never met her real grandparents until they left Cuba in 1970. This is important because early in the memoir she said her surrogate grandparents (Sergio, Edelmira) came to eat dinner. In conclusion, in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the story is shocking as her real grandparents came to the United States in 1970. She wanted to write this because she wanted to teach the reader to know the real definition of family, which goes beyond blood relations.

The mood created by the author is a loving and caring mood. In the second paragraph, he vividly describes the house as filled with the rich, flavorful culinary cooking of his parents. The passionate Cuban music fills the air, and the enticing aromas of the kitchen waft through their warm home. He tells that in their house, they often have feasts. Also, they invite many immigrants into their house and let them stay until they can leave on their own or find a place to live. He describes that family has nothing to do with blood relatives; everybody in their neighborhood is family, and they care for each other and any of the people who need help. At the end, he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." He tells how they taught him love and the real definition of family, and he describes their house as being a warm, inviting place that truly feels like home.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is love and happiness, emphasizing how family and friends are intertwined. In the memoir, he elaborates on how his mom and dad selflessly gave up everything for their child and his life. They had to completely change their lives after leaving Cuba. For instance, in Cuba, his dad had worked in a laboratory, and his mom had studied chemical engineering, and they might have to forgo these careers. This sacrifice and the unwavering love they showed create the warm and emotional mood in the memoir, highlighting the true meaning of family and the lengths parents will go for their children.

The mood of this memoir is one of deep - seated gratitude and contentment. The author conveys this mood through the carefully chosen quotes he inserts. "I was born into this simple house, which was situated in a two - family, blond - brick building in the ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." This quote indicates that the author did not place great importance on the house's appearance, price, or its location. "It was here where I learned the real definition of family... [that it] had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The author is truly grateful for all the people that he now considers his "family". Also, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life". The sense of gratitude is right there in the quote. The author also adds some phrases in parentheses, like "(after which I am eternally grateful)" and "(which I adore to this day)". These phrases clearly show that the author is happy and grateful with his life. The next quote further emphasizes that his "family" members were all grateful for each other. "It was a close - knit community of honest, hard - working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need". Overall, the memoir is a beautiful testament to the power of gratitude and the true meaning of family.

The mood created by the author is one of friendship and love. When the author's parents moved to the United States, they painstakingly created a traditional home, with the heart of it being the kitchen. "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the delicious aromas of the kitchen." During the kitchen celebrations throughout childhood, friends and family formed the perfect backdrop to their life. The author learned that '"family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative.' The neighborhood where the author lived was made up of many different cultures, yet they blended harmoniously with each other to form a small community of honest, hard - working immigrants who were always ready to help others when they themselves were in need. "My parent's always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family." The many immigrants gave up their lives in Cuba to move to the US to make a better life for their children, even though they were unfamiliar with the language and culture. The author will always be thankful to her parents for this selfless act. There is no way to fully show her thanks for her parents' love and sacrifice that they showed to her when she was just a child, and for showing her the importance of family and friends. The author states "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." They didn't just change it; they did it through the power of love and friendship. In essence, this memoir beautifully captures the essence of a loving and inclusive family.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound loving and caringness. Repeatedly throughout the memoir, the speaker, Narciso Rodriguez, reveals what his family did after migrating from their native country, Cuba, out of love. As mentioned, his parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family, knowing well that they would receive the same kindness in return. They cared deeply for their children's future, which led them to leave behind their families, friends, and established careers in the country they loved. Although "they struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships," they did what they thought was best for their children. Their simple house became the perfect place for them to be together as a family. "The warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just enticing scent and lively music but also life and love". This memoir made me draw a parallel between this family and mine, as they are strikingly similar. Without love, it isn't truly a family, which is why at the end of the word "family", the i, l, y stand for "i love you". In conclusion, the memoir is a touching ode to the power of family love.

This memoir gives me a sort of warm, cozy and comfortable feeling. When it talks about a family being not only people that are blood - related to you, I immediately think of my friends and the reliable people I can count on. They are my family too. He also elaborates on how a house is not necessarily a home; it can't be a home without memories, the presence of your family, and someone or something that you can whole - heartedly trust. Lastly, he tells us about how extremely grateful he is that his parents brought him to a neighborhood that he would soon learn to cherish deeply. This piece makes me pause and think about my own family and home, and it makes me truly appreciate them. In the end, the memoir serves as a gentle reminder of the significance of family and home in our lives.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a very positive and reassuring one. It is a good feeling that comes from the author's explanation of how he lived in a real - life situation. Having family come to live with you until they get back on their feet, having family all around you, and realizing that you've turned your "house into a Home" are all heart - warming aspects. Endless celebrations that encompass joy and togetherness form a beautiful backdrop to life in their warm home. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." "The barriers to work were strong and high and my parents both accepted that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they had deserved." "In Cuba, Narciso, Sr. had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied Chemical Engineering." In the new place, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. The unwavering faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times. This is what I perceived as the author's mood in the memoir, a blend of hope, sacrifice, and family love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is loving, caring, and full of gratefulness. Throughout the memoir, the author continuously and sincerely mentions how deeply grateful she is to her parents and how much she whole - heartedly loves them. She says that "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author means that she's truly thankful that her parents love her so much that they were willing to give up their home, stable jobs, and dear friends, all just to give her a better life. She also says that "what they [her parents] did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." Narciso is stating that it takes an enormous amount of courage to move forward into an unknown future, and she's extremely grateful that her parents had the bravery to do so. The quote clearly shows the loving, caring, and grateful mood expressed in the memoir by the author, making the readers feel the depth of her emotions.

The mood is a complex mixture of various things, and it's really hard to precisely define with all the emotions the author throws around. However, the strongest feeling is unity and a sense of family. I'm not entirely sure if family can be strictly called an emotion, but I think it can be described by several emotions. One of them, of course, is unity, or as he puts it, "great solidarity and friendship". It's rather sweet how he characterizes family as the bonds you form with people, in contrast to other cultures where family is mainly based on blood ties and family always comes first. So, in a way, I think his way of thinking stems from his unique cultural background. But also, he adds a bit of sadness, yet overall, he seems to be extremely thankful for what he has. As they say "happiness is nothing without appreciating it", and as he says "I learned the real definition of family", so apparently, he has truly grasped the essence of real happiness, which makes his account all the more touching.

The mood created in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is one of pure happiness, deep - seated peace, and heartfelt gratitude. Narciso is genuinely thankful for all that his parents had selflessly sacrificed and patiently taught him. His overall tone in the memoir is smoothly translated into a happy and peaceful mood. Narciso writes "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life to our warm home." The tone in this quote is calmly friendly, as Narciso vividly explains the immense happiness of his life at home. By saying his house was "warm" with continuous celebrations for family and friends, it effectively constructs the peaceful mood of the memoir. Narciso goes on to explain that "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family." Here, Rodriguez further adds to the peaceful mood by speaking of the generosity and care towards family. It is the beautiful idea of family that fueled his loving childhood. The mood turns to profound gratitude as Narciso thanks his parents for giving him a better life, though they had to endure difficult jobs and harsh conditions. He expresses that he had "no way to express [his] gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon [him]," and "the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The concepts of family, love, and generosity that Narciso learned from his parents formed the solid basis of the gracious, happy, and tranquil mood of his memoir, as well as his life, leaving a lasting impression on the readers.

The author created a tone in the memoir that was truly truthful, deeply grateful, and highly pride - inducing. "Passionate Cuban music... Filled the air, mixing with the enticing aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations... that formed the backdrop to life in our warm home" (@NUM1). The former quote, found in paragraph @NUM1, vividly described the pride and gratefulness of the home in which the author lived. The memoir created a strong sense of family love which every person yearns for in life. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM3). Anyone who can make such sacrifices for the better life of their family is truly a good person. That is the family love I am describing, being selfless and loving towards other members of your family. Another mood created in the memoir was pride in the family's sacrifice. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a more courageous thing than I could have ever done" (@NUM4). That was a quote from paragraph @NUM4. It clearly shows that one has to be truly thankful for the sacrifices people make for them. All of these elements make up the qualities of a wonderful family life, which the author beautifully portrays in the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy because the atmosphere is filled with the warmth of family and friends, along with an abundance of joy and happiness. They considered everyone as family, even though the times were not the best for everyone. Also, his parents made great sacrifices, giving up a lot so he could have a good life in @LOCATION1. He is extremely grateful for his parents' decision to bring him to @LOCATION1 so he could enjoy a good life, even though they had to leave their familiar life in Cuba to come here for him. This deep - seated gratitude and the happy atmosphere of family and friends combine to create the warm and positive mood in the memoir, making it a heart - warming read that touches the readers' souls.

The mood created by this memoir is a relaxed, caring kind of mood that envelops the reader like a warm embrace. Several parts of this work subtly yet effectively emphasize this soothing mood. The author often pens down his deep - seated love for his parents, highlighting their selflessness. He elaborates on how their selfless acts, like sacrificing their own desires for his well - being, have left an indelible mark on his heart. This emphasis on his love for his parents not only warms the narrative but also sets the tone of the relaxed, caring mood. Moreover, he repeats this sentiment many times throughout the memoir. This repetition acts like a gentle reminder, steadily building and reinforcing the mood with each mention. A final aspect that contributes to this mood is his vivid description of how everyone in his neighborhood was kind to each other. He tells of neighbors helping one another in times of need, sharing meals, and offering words of comfort. In conclusion, there are many things in this work that emphasize a relaxed, caring mood, making it a heartwarming read.

Within the cozy walls of Narciso's childhood home, her young parents created their traditional @CAPS1 abode. Their heart, the very center of their family life, was the kitchen. Narciso's parents both whole - heartedly shared the cooking duties. With each stir of the pot and flip of the pan, they unwittingly passed on their rich culinary skills to Narciso, who grew to love cooking with a passion. Quite the contrary, Narciso's neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish and Italian immigrants at a time when racism was unfortunately prevalent. Her parents came selflessly, as some immigrants will do, driven by the dream of giving their children a better life. They made the difficult sacrifice of leaving behind their family, friends, and well - established careers in the country they came from. I think her memory is a nice, happy one because with those memories, she clearly knows what her family went through, and it serves as a precious reminder of their love and determination.

The mood created by the author was a profound love from his family that permeates every page of the story. The author vividly describes "a love of (Cuban) cooking which is still with me (the author) today" and how "Passionate Cuban music which I (the author) still adore today." He recalls the warm evenings in the kitchen, the aroma of Cuban dishes filling the air, and the lively tunes of Cuban music playing in the background. This love was instilled in him by his parents, who were the keepers of these cultural treasures. Another way the author created the mood of love was by talking about how his "parents always kept their arms and door open." He explains that it was not just a physical act but a symbol of their open - heartedness and acceptance. I know that it takes a lot to be able to let anyone into your home, especially with such genuine warmth. The author is speaking very lovingly at this point in the story, his words dripping with affection. The author also says that he "will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice." This statement further sets the mood of the story because they are talking about a deep - seated, loving relationship. The mood that the author set during the story was love. I think that this was a really good mood to set in a story as it makes the narrative truly touching.

I think the mood created by the author was a deep - rooted gratefulness towards his parents. Narciso Rodriguez sincerely wants to tell his parents how very special they are to him and how much he thanks them for what they did for him. In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez says that "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." He remembers the times when his parents faced difficulties with unwavering resolve, which has always inspired him. I think that in this memoir, Narciso wants the reader to understand how he feels about his family. He wants to tell us about the countless sacrifices they made for him, like working long hours to provide for his needs. Narciso thanks his parents for their sacrifice and I think by telling us his story, the mood that was created was gratefulness towards the parents who made him a 'home'. This mood makes the memoir a poignant and heartfelt account of family love and sacrifice.

In this excerpt from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, @PERSON1  talks about the true meaning of "family" and the mood of gratitude is firmly established. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills... Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." In this passage, @PERSON2 is establishing his gratitude for the cultures of his family. He remembers the joy of sitting around the table, enjoying delicious Cuban food while listening to the lively music. He is grateful for the food and music that has wound its way into his present - day life, becoming an integral part of his identity. "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." This quote explains how much @PERSON1's parents sacrificed for his happiness. They left behind everything and everyone they loved, basically a huge chunk of themselves, and for that, he is extremely grateful. Through these descriptions, the mood of gratitude is powerfully conveyed, making the reader appreciate the sacrifices and love within the family.

The @CAPS1 in the @CAPS2 is truly distinct and unique compared to other things I have heard. I believe that the @CAPS1 the @CAPS3 is attempting to convey is happiness, self - lessness, and gratitude. I think this because he vividly describes his parents as selfless individuals who take everyone into their small apartment, showing a great deal of kindness and generosity. I also think he is creating a sense of "warmth" by stating that his first birthday with his parents was comforting. That is the @CAPS1 I firmly believe the @CAPS3 is trying to create, and it leaves a lasting impression.

The mood in this passage revolves around Narciso Rodriguez's home, nationality, and his family. He frequently talks about his nationality with pride. He is extremely proud to be born in Cuba and is not afraid to openly say it. He is also married and lives in the @DATE1's in America. He often mentions his @NUM1 - bedroom apartment in Newark, New Jersey, sharing details about his living space. He also likes to talk about the new friends he has made here, the bonds he has formed. And, of course, he talks about his family and his childhood. His neighborhood is composed of Cubans and @CAPS1, creating a unique and diverse community. That was the essence of the memoir in this passage, painting a vivid picture of his life.

The mood in the memoir is clearly one of gratitude. It is expressed in a few notable ways. One way is in paragraph six where he sincerely says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." This clearly shows that he is deeply grateful toward his parents because they made the brave move from Cuba to the @CAPS1. Another way is in paragraph @NUM1 where he fondly says "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I admire to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This shows that he is grateful toward his parents for their Cuban culture and specifically for passing on their wonderful cooking skills to him. These are the key reasons why the mood of the memoir is so strongly one of gratitude.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author in the memoir is one of deep gratitude. Narciso is truly thankful for his parents' unwavering support and love. When he expresses how he feels about his parents, he clearly states "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "grateful for their love and sacrifice" powerfully demonstrate that throughout his whole life, they were constantly there for him. They didn't just give him advice; they showed him the right way through their actions. When he talks about the @NUM2 important lessons he has learned from his parents, he says "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "basis of my life" clearly illustrate that they taught him the fundamental essentials of living. They also showed him the true meaning of family. He doesn't simply think family is just about blood relations, as he states "It was here when I learned the real definition of 'family'" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM4). The words "definition of family" show that he is truly thankful for them teaching him what family means to them. In conclusion, the mood of this passage is one of profound gratitude that permeates every part of the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a genuinely happy one. This is because in the memoir, Narciso was truly happy with all that his parents did for him. Their love, support, and the things they provided brought him great joy. Moreover, the neighborhood was a peaceful one. Everyone in the neighborhood reached out to help whoever needed it, creating a warm and friendly environment. This sense of community and the love from his parents combined to create a happy mood that is felt throughout the memoir, making it a heart - warming read.

The memoir looks back on his childhood with deep - seated fondness, so I'd firmly call the mood wistful. Yes, the author masterfully creates a wistful mood by vividly talking about his childhood home, the close - knit friends he had, and his loving family. But... this wistfulness only endures until the end of paragraph @NUM1. After that, it gracefully transitions into a grateful mood. In this part, he's earnestly giving out thanks and in - depthly describing what his parents had to go through. If it is indeed possible to have two moods within a single memoir, then this one surely does. The moods are both wistful and grateful, which together make the memoir rich and emotionally resonant.

The mood of the author and the memoir is clearly grateful. The author is extremely grateful for his parents. He is deeply thankful for them because they selflessly gave up their life for him. They made the difficult decision to move from their native country so that he could grow up in a better environment, specifically in @LOCATION1. His parents bravely quit their jobs and traveled far, all with his well - being in mind. He is also grateful for his extended family and friends. They are the ones with whom he shares meals, has fun playing, and spends quality time. He takes care of them, and in return, they take care of him. They serve as his surrogate grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins, and friends. He is also thankful for his culture. All his delicious food along with the cherished traditions come from Cuba. Overall, the author's gratitude permeates the memoir, making it a heart - warming read.

The mood that the author created in the memoir is a complex blend of sadness and happiness, and it truly holds the reader's interest. I think that this memoir is a well - crafted one, and I particularly liked the title of it, Narciso Rodriguez. The combination of these two contrasting moods makes the memoir more relatable and engaging. It allows the readers to experience a wide range of emotions, just like in real life. In conclusion, the unique mood and the appealing title make this memoir a worthwhile read.

The mood created by the author is both @CAPS1 and love. At first, the mood the author skillfully crafted was @CAPS1. In paragraph @NUM1, it clearly says "They struggled both personally and financially." Narciso poignantly explains the tragedies his parents had to face in order for him to live in @LOCATION1. So, by carefully reading the excerpt, based on the poverty and the hardships his family endured, it makes you naturally grow @CAPS1 for them. I also chose love. In the excerpt, it states, "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'." And for this valuable lesson, I will never forget that house or its kind - hearted neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. Throughout the excerpt, the author beautifully explains the love he learned to form for the "family" in the neighborhood. Therefore, that's why I think love is another prominent mood created by the author. In this memoir it delves deeply into what the true meaning of selflessness and a home truly is. The mood of this article created by Narciso Rodriguez in "The blueprints of our lives" is selflessness, admiration, gratitude, and thankfulness. The mood created by the author in the memoir is truly heart - warming. The author of the memoir is deeply thankful to her parents and to the rest of her family. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by The blueprints of our Lives, the mood the author created in the memoir was one of profound gratitude. The author created that mood because he was and is still extremely grateful about how his parents left behind their close - knit family and friends, as well as their stable jobs, so that he could have a better life. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, he creates a joyously happy and highly excited mood. This is because he is sharing precious family memories and those of his beloved home. The overall mood created by the author in the memoir was one of courage and perseverance. First, Narciso Rodriguez's parents traveled to the United States with absolutely nothing; they had no money and no prior background information about the country. The Rodriguez's also persevered through the harsh challenges of racism and segregation here in this country. The mood the author has in this memoir is happiness. He states that growing up in that particular environment gave him a strong sense of family. A sense of community, selflessness, and contentment washes over Narciso Rodriguez's memoir of his first home. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," Narciso Rodriguez says. The moods created in the memoir were all different. They talk about their family, friends, and how they transformed a simple apartment into a place called home. The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives" is clearly one of deep - seated compassion. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author depicts a mood with distinct and remarkable traits. One prominent trait of the mood is selflessness and courage. It is vividly shown in paragraph @NUM1 when the author says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." This statement clearly reflects the author's deep - seated gratefulness towards his parents for their selflessness and courage in coming over to @LOCATION2 to give him a better future. Finally, unity is prominently found in the mood. It is evident in paragraph @NUM3 when it says, "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures come together in great solidarity and friendship. This shows great unity in their neighborhood because in other parts of the United States, these three races didn't get along, but in this neighborhood they were unified. In conclusion, the author effectively depicts a mood with these distinct and inspiring traits, which leave a lasting impression on the readers.

Narciso said, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This statement shows that he has a genuine and heartfelt appreciation for what they did. He firmly believed that family encompasses everyone that you love and are close to, not just blood relatives. Narciso considered his community to be one giant, loving family. This memoir had an upbeat tone due to the unwavering positivity and optimism of the author, making it an engaging and inspiring read.

He creates a calming and outgoing mood for the stories he makes. The reader can vividly feel, smell, and hear the Cuban and Spanish influence around him in his home.
