From the reading "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives", by Narciso Rodriguez, a certain mood is set throughout the entire reading. That mood is a happy and friendly one. They based their lives on family and happiness inside their home. He said that "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open." This clearly shows that if family or friends needed help, they were always there for them. It also stated that people in your family don't have to be blood - related, and many people were welcome to eat dinner with them. This indicates how nice and how well the neighborhood got along. They would also surround themselves with Cuban food and music, showing that they were proud of who they were and that they made their new home a nice and peaceful environment, which truly reflects the warmth of family and community.

The author talks about home and family, which creates a calm, caring, and happy mood. The author created these moods by talking about memories and how her parents moved from Cuba to give their child a better life. They would take in family members in need until they got back on their feet. She said her parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to her their rich culinary skills and a love for cooking that still remains with her today. Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the wonderful aromas of the kitchen. This is like a happy mood. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This definitely shows a calm and happy mood, making the readers feel the charm of family and home.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood was very happy and made me thankful. My grandparents moved to the U.S. when my mom was just six. They wanted to give her and her brothers and sisters a better life. This is the main reason why I am thankful. I live in the United States. The mood is also happy because everyone loved each other. They didn't have the nicest home, but it was full of love. The music was always playing, and family came over a lot. The door was always open in the Rodriguez house. The last sentence in this memoir "I will never Forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This made me smile as it was so beautiful. This is how the mood was happy and made me thankful. The next time I see my grandparents, I will make sure to thank them for moving to the U.S. and giving our family a better life, as their sacrifice has brought so much happiness to us.

I believe the mood that sets off in the beginning of the story is how in her house, Cuban music and great aromas from Cuban cuisine fill the air. In the memoir, this is how the author crafted the mood. He vividly tells of how his parents lived in a dilapidated house where poverty was rampant at that time. The mood created by the author in the memoir is warm, grateful, and very palpable to the reader. One mood the author conveys very deeply is that of his profound love of his family. The mood of this memoir is one of love and kindness. The author creates a warm, happy, and grateful mood in the memoir. Here, the pure innocence of childhood, the joyous congregation of family and friends, and the endless celebrations that brought both together formed the idyllic backdrop to life in our cozy and inviting home. In our neighborhood, despite different customs found elsewhere, all of these diverse cultures came together in great solidarity and true friendship. I will always be deeply grateful to my parents for their unwavering love and selfless sacrifice. There is simply no way to fully express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity that was impressed upon me at such an early age and the powerful demonstration of how incredibly important family and friends are. It was in this simple yet charming house that my parents whole - heartedly welcomed other refugees to celebrate their new beginning in this country, and where I joyfully celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the comforting warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a traditional Cuban feast always filled the air not just with a delicious scent and lively music but also with life and love. It was where I truly learned the real definition of family. I will never forget that house, its kind - hearted neighborhood, or the many valuable lessons I learned there about how to love. I will always cherish how my parents turned this simple house into a loving and forever home.

In Narciso Rodriguez from: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author creates the mood of family and love in the memoir in a very vivid way. @PERSON1 was a young boy who lived with his loving parents in a three - room apartment. The heart of the house was indeed the kitchen, a place filled with warmth and activity. It was there that his parents patiently taught him to cook, sharing their culinary skills and traditions, and showed him the passionate Cuban music that filled the air with rhythm and joy. In the house, "...the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both formed the backdrop to life in our warm home (@NUM1). Then, @PERSON1 realized that " 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" (@NUM2), which showed that a neighborhood made up of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants could get along harmoniously. Many people had lived at the Rodriguez house, even if they weren't blood related. Some people were the landlord and his daughter, who lived upstairs, while the grandparents lived in the basement. Anyone in the neighborhood was welcome to stay, and they would usually stay in the house because they had an economic/money problem. @CAPS1, the Rodriguez family let people stay until they could get back on their feet. @CAPS1, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us" (@NUM3). "It was in this simple house... where I learned the real definition of "family." And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM4). This memoir beautifully captures the essence of family and love that transcends blood ties.

The author of this memoir created a very uplifting mood.
